content.text: Once upon a time, in a small village nestled between emerald-green rice fields and whispering bamboo groves, there lived a kind old man and his wife.
They were as poor as church mice, but their hearts were as warm as the sun that ripened their meager crops.
Every morning, the old man would rise with the roosters, tie a straw hat to his head, and trudge to the fields to tend to his rice plants.
His wife, with hands as gentle as falling petals, would stay behind to cook their simple meals.
One crisp autumn morning, the old woman decided to make onigiri—a plump, round rice ball—for her husband’s lunch.
She took steaming rice from the pot, pressed it between her palms, and wrapped it lovingly in a strip of seaweed.
But as she worked, her fingers, stiff with age, fumbled just once.
The rice ball slipped from her hands and—plop!—landed on the wooden floor.
Before she could catch it, the onigiri rolled right out the open door, down the dirt path, and into the tall grass beyond.
"Oh dear!" the old woman cried, clutching her apron.
She hurried after it, but the rice ball was already bouncing down the hill, as if it had a mind of its own.
It rolled past the startled chickens, who squawked and flapped their wings.
It tumbled over a sleeping cat, who yowled and leaped onto the fence.
It even dodged a curious puppy, who chased after it with wagging tail, only to trip over his own paws.
The rice ball rolled and rolled, faster and faster, until it reached the edge of the village.
There, it met a wide, rushing river, its waters sparkling like liquid silver under the sun.
The old woman gasped, certain her husband’s lunch was lost forever.
But just as the rice ball teetered on the bank, a mischievous wind swirled around it, giving it one last push—whoosh!—right into the river.
Now, the river was home to a great many creatures, but none as peculiar as a talking tanuki—a raccoon dog with a belly round as a barrel and a grin as wide as the moon.
The tanuki was lounging on a smooth rock, sunning himself, when splash!
the rice ball landed right in his lap. "Well, well!" the tanuki chuckled, picking up the onigiri.
"What do we have here? A gift from the river gods?" He sniffed it, his nose twitching.
"Mmm, seaweed and rice!
My favorite!" And with that, he opened his mouth wide—gulp!—and swallowed the rice ball in one bite.
But no sooner had he done so than his belly began to rumble.
Not with hunger, but with something far stranger. The tanuki clutched his stomach and let out a yelp.
"Ohhh, what’s happening to me?" he groaned. Before his eyes, his paws stretched and flattened.
His fur smoothed into soft, white rice. His round body swelled and took on the shape of—another rice ball!
"By the whiskers of my ancestors!" the tanuki cried, but his voice came out as a tiny squeak.
He had turned into an onigiri himself!
Now, the rice ball that was once the tanuki wobbled on the rock, feeling very confused.
"This is most inconvenient," he muttered (though, of course, he no longer had a mouth to mutter with).
Just then, a hungry fox trotted down to the riverbank, his golden eyes gleaming.
He sniffed the air and spotted the rice ball. "Ah-ha!" the fox said, licking his lips.
"A snack just for me!" And with that, he snatched up the rice ball-tanuki and took a big bite.
But the moment the fox’s teeth sank into the rice, poof! The tanuki’s magic worked its mischief again.
The fox’s jaws clamped down on nothing but air as the rice ball vanished—and in its place stood the tanuki, whole and furry once more, rubbing his belly with a grin.
"Well, that was unexpected," the tanuki said, stretching.

"But I suppose I should return this rice ball to its rightful owner." And with that, he scooped up the original onigiri (which had been sitting innocently on the rock all along) and set off toward the village.
Meanwhile, the old woman had given up her chase and returned home, sighing.
"I’ve lost my husband’s lunch," she told him when he arrived, her voice heavy with regret.
The old man patted her hand. "Never mind, my dear.
We’ll share what we have."  But just as they were about to eat their meager supper, there came a knock at the door.
The old woman opened it to find the tanuki standing there, holding out the rice ball.
"I believe this belongs to you," he said with a bow. The old woman’s eyes widened. "Oh! My onigiri!
But how—?"  The tanuki winked. "Let’s just say it had quite the adventure.
But I thought it best to return it before it rolled any farther."  The old man and woman were overjoyed.
They invited the tanuki inside, and the three of them shared the rice ball, along with the rest of their simple meal.
The tanuki told them tales of his own adventures, and the old couple listened with laughter and wonder.
From that day on, the tanuki became a frequent visitor to their home, always bringing gifts from the forest—a basket of mushrooms, a bundle of sweet persimmons, or a jar of golden honey.
And though the old man and woman remained poor, their lives were rich with kindness, laughter, and the magic of unexpected friends.
And as for the rice ball? Well, it never rolled away again.
But sometimes, on quiet evenings, the old woman would swear she heard a faint giggle coming from the kitchen, as if the onigiri itself were still playing tricks.
